qa_list.question: What is the purpose of providing shared office space for full-time students in the LTI’s MIIS program?
qa_list.answer: The purpose of providing a shared office space for full-time students in the LTI's MIIS program is to create a sense of community among them.

qa_list.question: What are the system requirements for laptops used by Master’s students at this university?
qa_list.answer: Master's students are expected to provide their own laptop computers that can run Windows, MacOS, or Linux software. They also need a CS user id to access the LTI computer cluster and other SCS services.

qa_list.question: Where is the Help Center located for Master’s students in the School of Computer Science?
qa_list.answer: The Help Center for Master's students in the School of Computer Science is located at MIIS Graduate Student Handbook, Page 10.

qa_list.question: What are the benefits of having a CS user id for Master’s students?
qa_list.answer: Having a CS user id allows Master's students to access the LTI computer cluster and other SCS services, which they need to complete their course assignments.

qa_list.question: What kind of software are laptops running in this university?
qa_list.answer: Laptops at this university can run Windows, MacOS, or Linux software.

qa_list.question: Why do Master’s students need to provide their own laptop computers?
qa_list.answer: Master's students are expected to bring their own laptops because they will be used for accessing university resources and completing course assignments.

qa_list.question: What is the purpose of providing a shared office space in this program?
qa_list.answer: The purpose of providing a shared office space in this program is to foster a sense of community among students, which can enhance their learning experience.

qa_list.question: What are the requirements for using the LTI computer cluster and other SCS services?
qa_list.answer: To use the LTI computer cluster and other SCS services, Master's students need to have a CS user id. This is required for accessing these resources.

qa_list.question: What does MIIS stand for in this context?
qa_list.answer: In this context, MIIS stands for the Master of International and Intercultural Studies program at the university.

qa_list.question: What is GHC 4201?
qa_list.answer: GHC 4201 refers to the contact information for a specific department at Carnegie Mellon University.

qa_list.question: Who can access the LTI's computer cluster and why?
qa_list.answer: MS students can access the LTI's computer cluster, which is used for course assignments, directed study projects, and/or the capstone project involving large datasets or lengthy computations.

qa_list.question: What are the standard program lengths for graduate students at Carnegie Mellon University?
qa_list.answer: The standard program lengths vary significantly ranging from two semesters for some full-time master’s programs to several or more years for doctoral programs.

qa_list.question: How is a degree certified at Carnegie Mellon University?
qa_list.answer: Upon completion of the graduate program degree requirements, the degree will be certified by the student’s academic program in the semester in which the student completes the requirements.

qa_list.question: What are the circumstances under which a graduate student can obtain early degree certification?
qa_list.answer: Graduate students who consider the completion of all degree requirements in less than the standard length of time for their program of study may consult with their degree-granting program or department to determine if early degree certification is allowed and under what circumstances.

qa_list.question: What are some reasons that might lead to longer-than-standard completion of a graduate degree?
qa_list.answer: Longer-than-standard degree completion may occur due to academic interruptions in making progress toward the degree as defined by the academic program, interruptions of full-time study or progress towards the degree due to serious, documented medical issues, or other unusual or unforeseen circumstances.

qa_list.question: What is GHC 4201 used for?
qa_list.answer: GHC 4201 refers to a contact point at Carnegie Mellon University. It can be reached by calling extension 8-4231 from a campus phone or 412-268-4231 from an outside line.

qa_list.question: What is the purpose of LTI's computer cluster?
qa_list.answer: The LTI’s computer cluster provides storage and computation for projects involving large datasets or lengthy computations, which can be used by MS students for course assignments, directed study projects, and/or the capstone project.

qa_list.question: What is the standard length of time for a master's program at Carnegie Mellon University?
qa_list.answer: The standard length of time for a full-time master’s program can vary, but it typically ranges from two semesters.

qa_list.question: How are graduate students expected to complete their degree requirements at Carnegie Mellon University?
qa_list.answer: Carnegie Mellon graduate students are expected to complete their degree requirements within the standard length of time for their program of study as outlined in the relevant Graduate Student Handbook.

qa_list.question: What are some reasons why a Master's student might require longer than the standard time to complete their degree?
qa_list.answer: A Master's student may require longer than the standard time to complete their degree due to academic interruptions in making progress toward the degree as defined by the academic program, interruptions of full-time study or progress towards the degree due to serious, documented medical issues, or other unusual or unforeseen circumstances.

qa_list.question: What is expected from Master's students who require longer than the standard time to complete their degree?
qa_list.answer: Master’s students who require longer than the standard time to complete their degree requirements are expected to remain in close contact with their graduate program, and will be certified at the end of the semester in which they have completed their degree requirements.

qa_list.question: Where can Master's students find guidelines and restrictions regarding the maximum length of time allowable for master’s degree completion?
qa_list.answer: Master's students should reference CMU Policy on Master’s Student Statute of Limitations: www.cmu.edu/policies/student-and-student-life/masters-students-statute-of limitations.html for guidelines and restrictions regarding the maximum length of time allowable for master’s degree completion.

qa_list.question: What is the source of this information?
qa_list.answer: This information comes from the MIIS Graduate Student Handbook, specifically page 11.

qa_list.question: How can Master's students remain in close contact with their graduate program if they require longer than the standard time to complete their degree?
qa_list.answer: Master’s students who require longer than the standard time to complete their degree requirements are expected to remain in close contact with their graduate program.

qa_list.question: What happens at the end of the semester when Master's students have completed all their degree requirements?
qa_list.answer: At the end of the semester, Master’s students who have completed their degree requirements will be certified.

qa_list.question: What is the purpose of the CMU Policy on Master’s Student Statute of Limitations?
qa_list.answer: The purpose of the CMU Policy on Master’s Student Statute of Limitations is to provide guidelines and restrictions regarding the maximum length of time allowable for master’s degree completion.

qa_list.question: What does 'interruptions in making progress toward the degree as defined by the academic program' mean?
qa_list.answer: Interruptions in making progress toward the degree as defined by the academic program refer to situations where a student is unable to continue their studies according to the requirements set forth by their graduate program.

qa_list.question: What does 'unusual or unforeseen circumstances' mean?
qa_list.answer: Unusual or unforeseen circumstances refer to situations that are not typical or expected, and which may cause a student to require longer than the standard time to complete their degree.

qa_list.question: What is the maximum time a student has to complete all requirements for a master's degree according to the Master’s Students Statute of Limitations?
qa_list.answer: The maximum time a student has to complete all requirements for a master's degree, as outlined in the Master’s Students Statute of Limitations, is seven years from original matriculation as a master’s student.

qa_list.question: What happens if a person fails to meet this time-to-degree limit?
qa_list.answer: If the time-to-degree limit has lapsed, the person may resume work towards a master’s degree only if newly admitted to a currently offered master’s degree program under criteria determined by that program.

qa_list.question: Under what circumstances can a school or college defer the lapse of the time-to-degree limit?
qa_list.answer: A school or college may, upon the relevant department's recommendation and with the written approval of the dean (or designate), defer the lapse for a period commensurate with the duration of that interruption.

qa_list.question: Who should students seek guidance from regarding their program of study and degree requirements?
qa_list.answer: Students seeking guidance about their program of study and degree requirements should consult with their academic advisor and/or appropriate associate dean.

qa_list.question: What happens if a student is pursuing a master’s degree as part-time students for all semesters of their program?
qa_list.answer: Students who are pursuing a master’s degree as part-time students for all semesters of their program, as approved by their program, may also appeal to their program or department for extension of the time to degree limit.

qa_list.question: What does 'matriculation' mean in this context?
qa_list.answer: In this context, matriculation refers to the process of becoming a master’s student.

qa_list.question: Does the Master’s Students Statute of Limitations apply to all students or only certain ones?
qa_list.answer: The Master’s Students Statute of Limitations applies to all students, but it may be more restrictive in some departments, schools, or colleges.

qa_list.question: What does 'defer the lapse' mean?
qa_list.answer: To defer the lapse means to postpone the expiration of the time-to-degree limit for a period commensurate with the duration of an interruption.

qa_list.question: What does 'part-time' mean in this context?
qa_list.answer: In this context, part-time refers to students who are pursuing their master’s degree on a less than full-time basis.

qa_list.question: Who should students consult for guidance about their program of study and degree requirements?
qa_list.answer: Students seeking guidance about their program of study and degree requirements should consult with their academic advisor and/or appropriate associate dean.

qa_list.question: What are the consequences if students do not make normal progress towards their degree in a standard timeframe?
qa_list.answer: Under U.S. Federal Title IV regulations, student eligibility for federal financial aid is contingent upon enrollment in and successful completion of courses that are counted as credit toward their current degree program. To receive the maximum amount of federal financial aid for which they may be eligible, students must enroll each semester in at least 36 units that count towards their current degree level.

qa_list.question: Who should international students consult if they are considering early completion or longer-than standard completion of their degree?
qa_list.answer: International Students Immigration status for students in F-1 and J-1 nonimmigrant status is tied to making normal progress toward completing degree requirements. Therefore, F-1 and J-1 students who are considering completing their degree requirements early, anticipating longer-than-standard completion, or moving from an undergraduate to a graduate student classification (integrated undergraduate-graduate study) should consult with their designated advisor in the Office of International Education (OIE) to ensure compliance with immigration regulations.

qa_list.question: Where can students find guidance regarding billing and financial aid?
qa_list.answer: Students should consult with their designated college liaison in The HUB regarding billing and financial aid, particularly for early completion, longer-than standard completion, or integrated undergraduate and master’s degree programs.

qa_list.question: What is the page number of this text?
qa_list.answer: Page 12

qa_list.question: Who should students consult if they are considering moving from an undergraduate to a graduate student classification (integrated undergraduate-graduate study)?
qa_list.answer: Students who are considering moving from an undergraduate to a graduate student classification (integrated undergraduate-graduate study) should consult with their designated advisor in the Office of International Education (OIE).

qa_list.question: What is the consequence if students do not enroll each semester in at least 36 units that count towards their current degree level?
qa_list.answer: Under U.S. Federal Title IV regulations, student eligibility for federal financial aid is contingent upon enrollment in and successful completion of courses that are counted as credit toward their current degree program. If students do not enroll each semester in at least 36 units that count towards their current degree level, they may lose their eligibility for the maximum amount of federal financial aid.

qa_list.question: What is the purpose of this text?
qa_list.answer: The purpose of this text is to provide guidance and information about student's program of study, degree requirements, financial aid, billing, and immigration status for international students.

qa_list.question: What should F-1 and J-1 students do if they are considering early completion or longer-than standard completion?
qa_list.answer: F-1 and J-1 students who are considering completing their degree requirements early, anticipating longer-than-standard completion, or moving from an undergraduate to a graduate student classification (integrated undergraduate-gradaduate study) should consult with their designated advisor in the Office of International Education (OIE).

qa_list.question: What are the two options for obtaining a Master of Science in Intelligent Information Systems degree?
qa_list.answer: The MIIS degree is offered in two options: Option 1. Standard MIIS degree (MIIS-16) - A 16-month track that is completed in three academic semesters (fall, spring, fall) and a summer internship. Option 2. MIIS: Advanced Study degree (MIIS-21) - A 21-month track that is completed in four academic semesters (fall, spring, fall, spring) and a summer internship.

qa_list.question: What are the areas of concentration offered for MIIS: Advanced Study degree?
qa_list.answer: MIIS: Advanced Study track offers in depth degree in one of the following areas of concentration: Human Language for Language Technologies • Language Technology Application • Machine Learning for Language Technologies

qa_list.question: How many units are required to attain a Standard MIIS-16 degree?
qa_list.answer: MIIS-16 students must take at least 84 units (typically 7 12-unit courses) of qualifying and elective courses that satisfy human language, machine learning, and language technology applications breadth requirements and 66 practice units for a total of 150 units to attain the Standard MIIS degree.

qa_list.question: How many units are required to attain an MIIS-21 Advanced Study degree?
qa_list.answer: MIIS-21 students must take at least 108 units (typically 9 12-unit courses) of qualifying and elective courses and 66 practice units to satisfy their degree requirements, making it a total of 174 units to attain the MIIS: Advanced Study degree.

qa_list.question: What are the three types of requirements for completing Master of Science in Intelligent Information Systems?
qa_list.answer: Curricular requirements ensure that MIIS students receive instruction in core intelligent information systems technologies while also allowing an opportunity to specialize in areas of personal interest. Practice requirements are opportunities to apply and hone new skills while building state-of-the-art systems. Grade requirements ensure that students have demonstrated a certain level of skill while completing degree requirements.

qa_list.question: What is the total number of units required for both MIIS-16 and MIIS-21 degrees?
qa_list.answer: The total number of units required for both MIIS-16 and MIIS-21 degrees combined is 332 units.

qa_list.question: What are the breadth requirements for a Standard MIIS degree?
qa_list.answer: The breadth requirements for a Standard MIIS degree include human language, machine learning, and language technology applications.

qa_list.question: How many practice units are required to attain both MIIS-16 and MIIS-21 degrees?
qa_list.answer: Both MIIS-16 and MIIS-21 degrees require a total of 66 practice units.

qa_list.question: What is the purpose of grade requirements in Master of Science in Intelligent Information Systems?
qa_list.answer: Grade requirements ensure that students have demonstrated a certain level of skill while completing degree requirements.

qa_list.question: How many academic semesters are there for MIIS-21 Advanced Study track?
qa_list.answer: The MIIS: Advanced Study track is completed in four academic semesters (fall, spring, fall, spring).

qa_list.question: What are the minimum number of units required for a MIIS-16 student to pass?
qa_list.answer: MIIS-16 students must complete 72 units, typically by passing six 12-unit courses.

qa_list.question: What is the definition of a qualifying master’s course for MIIS students?
qa_list.answer: A qualifying master's course includes any graduate course (600-level or higher) offered by the Language Technologies Institute and any graduate course from the list of approved qualifying courses.

qa_list.question: What is a free elective for MIIS students?
qa_list.answer: A free elective includes any graduate course (600-level or higher) with content relevant to the MIIS program objectives offered by the School of Computer Science, and courses approved by the student's advisor and degree Program Director.

qa_list.question: What are the breadth requirements for MIIS students?
qa_list.answer: MIIS students must demonstrate breadth by passing one course in each of the following areas: Human language, Machine learning, and Language technology applications. Additionally, MIS-21 students must take two more LTI courses (24 units total) in one of these areas.

qa_list.question: What are the approved qualifying courses for MIIS students?
qa_list.answer: Any graduate course (600-level or higher) offered by the Language Technologies Institute and any two graduate courses (600-level or higher) offered by departments within the SCS relevant to the MIIS degree other than LTI (Machine Learning or Computer Science departments, etc.) are approved qualifying courses.

qa_list.question: Can a student use the same course to satisfy both a qualifying course requirement and an elective course requirement?
qa_list.answer: No, a student may not use the same course to satisfy both a qualifying course requirement and an elective course requirement.

qa_list.question: What is the minimum number of units required for a MIIS-21 student to pass?
qa_list.answer: MIIS-21 students must complete 96 units, typically by passing eight 12-unit courses.

qa_list.question: What are the areas of concentration that MIS-21 students can choose from for their breadth requirements?
qa_list.answer: MIIS-21 students must take two more LTI courses (24 units total) in one of the following areas: Human language, Machine learning, and Language technology applications.

qa_list.question: What is the department that maintains and publishes a list of courses satisfying each breadth requirement?
qa_list.answer: The department responsible for maintaining and publishing a list of courses satisfying each breadth requirement is the Language Technologies Institute.

qa_list.question: What are the requirements for a graduate course to be considered an approved qualifying course?
qa_list.answer: A graduate course (600-level or higher) offered by the Language Technologies Institute is considered an approved qualifying course.

qa_list.question: Can courses from departments within SCS relevant to MIIS degree be counted as approved qualifying courses?
qa_list.answer: Yes, any two graduate courses (600-level or higher) offered by departments within the SCS relevant to the MIIS degree other than LTI (Machine Learning or Computer Science departments, etc.) may be counted as approved qualifying courses.

qa_list.question: Where can I find information about the requirements for graduate courses to be considered an approved qualifying course?
qa_list.answer: The information about the requirements for a graduate course to be considered an approved qualifying course is found in the MIIS Graduate Student Handbook, page 14.

qa_list.question: What are the departments within SCS relevant to MIIS degree?
qa_list.answer: The departments within SCS (School of Computer Science) that are relevant to the MIIS (Master's in Information Systems) degree, excluding LTI and Machine Learning or Computer Science departments, etc., are not specified.

qa_list.question: What is the minimum level required for a course to be considered an approved qualifying course?
qa_list.answer: The minimum level required for a course to be considered an approved qualifying course is 600-level or higher.

qa_list.question: Can courses from the Language Technologies Institute (LTI) be counted as approved qualifying courses?
qa_list.answer: Yes, any graduate course (600-level or higher) offered by the Language Technologies Institute is considered an approved qualifying course.

qa_list.question: What is the source of information about approved qualifying courses for MIIS students?
qa_list.answer: The information about approved qualifying courses for MIIS (Master's in Information Systems) students can be found in the MIIS Graduate Student Handbook, page 14.

qa_list.question: What is the maximum number of graduate courses from departments within SCS relevant to MIIS degree that a student can count as approved qualifying courses?
qa_list.answer: The text does not specify the maximum number of graduate courses from departments within SCS (School of Computer Science) relevant to the MIIS (Master's in Information Systems) degree that a student can count as approved qualifying courses.

qa_list.question: What is the purpose of the MIIS Graduate Student Handbook?
qa_list.answer: The purpose of the MIIS Graduate Student Handbook is to provide information about requirements, policies, and procedures for students pursuing a Master's in Information Systems degree.

qa_list.question: What are the approved qualifying courses for Any course from the following list is an approved qualifying course.?
qa_list.answer: 02-712, Computational Methods for Biological Modeling and Simulation • 05-631, Software Structures for User interfaces • 05-813, Human Factors • • • • 10-708, Probabilistic Graphical Models 16-720, Computer Vision 17-631 Information Security, Privacy & Policy 17-781, Mobile and IoT Computing Services

qa_list.question: What are the breadth courses in Human Language?
qa_list.answer: 11-611, Natural Language Processing 11-624, Human Language for Artificial Intelligence 11-711, Advanced NLP 11-722, Grammar Formalisms 11-724, Human Language for Artificial Intelligence 11-727, Computational Semantics for NLP 11-737, Multilingual NLP

qa_list.question: What are the breadth courses in Language Technology Applications?
qa_list.answer: 11-642, Search Engines 11-688, Concepts in Digital Multimedia and Cyber Forensics 11-692, Speech Processing 11-697. Introduction to Question Answering 11-751, Speech Recognition and Understanding 11-767, On-Service Machine Learning 11-797, Question Answering 11-830, Computational Ethics For NLP

qa_list.question: What are the breadth courses in Machine Learning?
qa_list.answer: 11-641, Machine Learning for Text and Graph-Based Mining 11-661, Language and Statistics 11-663, Applied Machine Learning 11-747, Neural Networks for NLP 11-755, Machine Learning for Signal Processing 11-761, Language and Statistics 11-777, Multimodal Machine Learning

qa_list.question: What is the name of the graduate student handbook?
qa_list.answer: MIIS Graduate Student Handbook

qa_list.question: On which page can you find information about qualifying courses, breadth courses and machine learning courses in this text?
qa_list.answer: Page 15

qa_list.question: How many approved qualifying courses are mentioned in the given list?
What is the total number of breadth courses mentioned for each category: Human Language, Language Technology Applications and Machine Learning?
qa_list.answer: Human Language - 6; Language Technology Applications - 7; Machine Learning - 4

qa_list.question: How many pages does the MIIS Graduate Student Handbook have?
What is the name of the course that focuses on computational methods for biological modeling and simulation?
qa_list.answer: 02-712, Computational Methods for Biological Modeling and Simulation

qa_list.question: Which page number is mentioned in the text as the source of information about qualifying courses, breadth courses and machine learning courses?
qa_list.answer: Page 15

qa_list.question: What are the courses offered for Master's and PhD programs in Machine Learning?
qa_list.answer: The courses offered for Master's and PhD programs in Machine Learning include 10-601, Introduction to Machine Learning (Master’s), 10-605, Machine Learning with Large Datasets, 10-701, Introduction to Machine Learning (PhD), 10-707, Advanced Deep Learning, and 10-708, Probabilistic Graphical Models.

qa_list.question: What is the directed study requirement for MIIS-16 and MIIS-21 programs?
qa_list.answer: The directed study requirement for MIIS-16 and MIIS-21 programs involves passing 24 units (typically 12 units x 2 semesters) in a structured, task-oriented form of independent study under the supervision of their advisor.

qa_list.question: What is the internship requirement for MIIS-16 and MIIS-21 programs?
qa_list.answer: The internship requirement for MIIS-16 and MIIS-21 programs involves completing a one-semester (typically summer) internship at an organization approved by the MIIS Program Director. Students with prior professional experience may petition to waive this requirement.

qa_list.question: How many practice-oriented course units are required for both MIIS-16 and MIIS-21 programs?
qa_list.answer: A student must complete at least 66 practice-oriented course units for both MIIS-16 and MIIS-21 programs.

qa_list.question: What is the requirement for students who do an internship during the summer semester?
qa_list.answer: Students who do an internship during the summer semester are required to present their internship at a poster session at the beginning of the following Fall semester. The poster and the student’s participation in the poster session are part of the internship requirement.

qa_list.question: What is the waiver for students who have prior professional experience?
qa_list.answer: Students with prior professional experience may petition the MIIS Program Director to waive the internship requirement.

qa_list.question: How many units are required in directed study under the supervision of their advisor for both MIIS-16 and MIIS-21 programs?
qa_list.answer: Both MIIS-16 and MIIS-21 programs require 24 units (typically 12 units x 2 semesters) in directed study under the supervision of their advisor.

qa_list.question: What are the courses offered for Master's program in Machine Learning?
qa_list.answer: The courses offered for Master's program in Machine Learning include 10-601, Introduction to Machine Learning (Master’s), 10-605, Machine Learning with Large Datasets, and 10-701, Introduction to Machine Learning (PhD).

qa_list.question: What are the courses offered for PhD program in Machine Learning?
qa_list.answer: The courses offered for PhD program in Machine Learning include 10-605, Machine Learning with Large Datasets and 10-701, Introduction to Machine Learning (PhD).

qa_list.question: What are the practice-oriented requirements for both MIIS-16 and MIIS-21 programs?
qa_list.answer: Both MIIS-16 and MIIS-21 programs require a student to complete at least 66 practice-oriented course units, pass 24 units in directed study under the supervision of their advisor, and complete a one-semester internship at an organization approved by the MIIS Program Director.

qa_list.question: What are the requirements for completing a capstone project in MIIS Graduate Student Handbook?
qa_list.answer: Students must complete a capstone project (36 units) and a capstone planning seminar (6 units).

qa_list.question: What is the purpose of the capstone requirement in MIIS Graduate Student Handbook?
qa_list.answer: The capstone requirement gives students experience with collaborative, team-oriented software development; significant hands-on experience with the techniques studied in the classroom; and an opportunity to work on a large software application.

qa_list.question: What is the nature of the capstone project?
qa_list.answer: The capstone project (36 units) is a large, group-oriented demonstration of student skill in one or more areas covered by the degree. Typically, the result of the capstone project is a major software application.

qa_list.question: Who supervises the capstone project?
qa_list.answer: The capstone project is supervised by a member of the faculty who meets with students on a weekly basis to monitor progress and provide guidance.

qa_list.question: What is the purpose of the capstone planning seminar?
qa_list.answer: The capstone planning seminar organizes students into groups, defines project goals and requirements, identifies resources needed for successful completion, and must be completed in the semester prior to taking the capstone project.

qa_list.question: How do students register for their courses?
qa_list.answer: Students use the Stellic Degree Audit Application to monitor progress, search for relevant courses, and share plans with advisors. They confirm enrollment status, class level, college, and department in SIO Academic Info.

qa_list.question: What are the steps students need to follow to complete registration within SIO?
qa_list.answer: Students must ensure their Enrollment Status is 'Eligible to Enroll', confirm maximum units, and check class level, college, and department. They then navigate to SIO Academic Info, select Enrollment Status and the upcoming semester, and follow 4 easy steps provided by CMU.

qa_list.question: Who can students contact for questions about course selection?
qa_list.answer: Students may reach out to MIIS program director Teruko Mitamura with any questions about course selection.

qa_list.question: What are the procedures and deadlines for adding, dropping, or withdrawing from courses?
qa_list.answer: Undergraduate and master’s level students must follow the procedures and deadlines identified on the academic calendar. Doctoral course changes have a separate calendar.

qa_list.question: What is the purpose of the Transfer Courses section in the MIIS Graduate Student Handbook?
qa_list.answer: The Transfer Courses and Pittsburgh Council on Higher Education (PCHE) section provides information about transferring courses from other institutions to MIIS.

qa_list.question: What is the purpose of the capstone project in a student's academic journey?
qa_list.answer: The capstone project serves as a culminating experience for students, demonstrating their mastery of skills and knowledge gained throughout their program.

qa_list.question: What is the role of the MIIS program director in assisting students?
qa_list.answer: The MIIS program director assists students with course selection, providing guidance on choosing appropriate courses for their academic goals and interests.

qa_list.question: How can students confirm their enrollment status and maximum units allowed in SIO?
qa_list.answer: Students should navigate to the SIO Academic Info tab, select Enrollment Status and the upcoming semester, and check for 'Eligible to Enroll' status. They also verify class level, college, and department.

qa_list.question: What is the process students must follow to complete registration within SIO?
qa_list.answer: Students should ensure their enrollment status is 'Eligible to Enroll', confirm maximum units allowed, check class level, college, and department. Then they navigate to SIO Academic Info, select Enrollment Status and the upcoming semester, and follow 4 easy steps provided by CMU.

qa_list.question: What is the purpose of the academic calendar for adding, dropping, or withdrawing from courses?
qa_list.answer: The academic calendar provides deadlines and procedures for undergraduate and master’s level students to add, drop, or withdraw from courses.

qa_list.question: What is Carnegie Mellon University's policy regarding transfer credit from other accredited institutions?
qa_list.answer: Carnegie Mellon University records information on courses taken through the university's cross-registration program and transfer credit from other accredited institutions. Courses taken through the university's cross-registration program will have grades recorded on the transcript and be factored into the QPA, while all other courses will be recorded without grades.

qa_list.question: Can suspended students receive transfer credit from other institutions?
qa_list.answer: Suspended students may take courses elsewhere but can only receive transfer credit if their college’s and department's policies allow this.

qa_list.question: What are the requirements for internships with units attached to them at Carnegie Mellon University?
qa_list.answer: Students taking internships with units attached must provide interim and final reports on their experience, presentations in the following semester regarding their experience, assessments of how their experience relates to their course of study.

qa_list.question: How does Carnegie Mellon University support students seeking internships?
qa_list.answer: The university and LTI provide several types of support for students seeking internships. Students are responsible for identifying and applying for internships on their own.

qa_list.question: What is the role of Carnegie Mellon University's transcript in recording cross-registration program courses?
qa_list.answer: Carnegie Mellon University's transcript records information on courses taken through the university's cross-registration program and courses taken at other accredited institutions. Courses taken through the university's cross-registration program will have grades recorded on the transcript and be factored into the QPA, while all other courses will be recorded without grades.

qa_list.question: What is the purpose of including information about internships in a student's academic record?
qa_list.answer: The inclusion of internship information in a student's academic record allows for assessments of how their experience relates to their course of study.

qa_list.question: What is the QPA and what role does it play in Carnegie Mellon University?
qa_list.answer: The QPA (Quality Point Average) is a measure used by Carnegie Mellon University to evaluate academic performance. It factors into consideration grades recorded on the transcript from courses taken at Carnegie Mellon and through cross-registration programs.

qa_list.question: What are the requirements for students taking internships with units attached?
qa_list.answer: Students taking internships with units attached must provide interim and final reports on their experience, presentations in the following semester regarding their experience, assessments of how their experience relates to their course of study.

qa_list.question: What is Carnegie Mellon University's policy for suspended students taking courses elsewhere?
qa_list.answer: Suspended students may take courses elsewhere but can only receive transfer credit if their college’s and department's policies allow this.

qa_list.question: What is the role of Carnegie Mellon University in supporting students seeking internships?
qa_list.answer: The university and LTI provide several types of support for students seeking internships. Students are responsible for identifying and applying for internships on their own.

qa_list.question: What services does the Career & Professional Development Center provide to help MIIS students prepare for internships?
qa_list.answer: The university offers resume-writing and interviewing workshops, as well as fall and spring employment fairs.

qa_list.question: What happens if a student cannot find an internship through the MIIS program?
qa_list.answer: If a student cannot find an internship, the MIIS program will arrange an on-campus internship with a university-based project. This internship may be unpaid.

qa_list.question: What is required for international students seeking an internship/co-op or signing an offer contract?
qa_list.answer: International students are required to consult with the Office of International Education for eligibility before seeking an internship/co-op or signing an offer contract.

qa_list.question: Where can MIIS students find information from other LTI professional master’s programs about their poster sessions?
qa_list.answer: MIIS students may attend similar internship-oriented poster sessions held by other LTI professional master’s programs.

qa_list.question: What is the purpose of an annual poster session at MIIS?
qa_list.answer: An annual poster session helps spread information from MIIS students that recently completed internships to MIIS students that will soon seek internships.

qa_list.question: Where can MIIS students find the Career & Professional Development Center's services?
qa_list.answer: MIIS students can access the university’s Career & Professional Development Center at https://www.cmu.edu/career/. This page provides other services as well.

qa_list.question: What is mentioned in section 4.10 of the MIIS Graduate Student Handbook?
qa_list.answer: Section 4.10 of the MIIS Graduate Student Handbook discusses advising services for students.

qa_list.question: What is the purpose of the university's Career & Professional Development Center?
qa_list.answer: The university’s Career & Professional Development Center provides various resources and services to help MIIS students prepare for internships, employment fairs, and other career opportunities.

qa_list.question: What is the location of the Office of International Education at MIIS?
qa_list.answer: The location of the Office of International Education at MIIS is not specified in the given text.

qa_list.question: What is the role of faculty advisor in guiding students through the program?
qa_list.answer: The faculty advisor's role includes guiding education, monitoring student progress, supervising directed study projects and providing career advice.

qa_list.question: When are advisors selected for each student?
qa_list.answer: Advisors are chosen during the first month of the program. Students attend LTI Orientation Faculty Research Talks to meet potential advisors, who describe their interests and areas of expertise.

qa_list.question: What happens if a student does not find an advisor after one month in the program?
qa_list.answer: If a student fails to secure an advisor within the first month, the Program Director assigns an advisor to them.

qa_list.question: Is it possible for students to change their advisors? If so, how?
qa_list.answer: Yes, students can switch advisors. They must find a new faculty member willing to serve as an advisor and then request the Program Director's approval.

qa_list.question: What is the policy regarding changing advisors in SCS?
qa_list.answer: The LTI follows the long-standing SCS policy that both the new and old advisors must agree to the change. This usually isn't a problem, as the new advisor has agreed beforehand.

qa_list.question: Why is it beneficial for students not to switch advisors frequently?
qa_list.answer: Forming a strong student-advisor relationship takes time and effort. Switching often can disrupt this process, making it harder for the student to benefit from their advisor's guidance.

qa_list.question: What is LTI Orientation?
qa_list.answer: LTI Orientation is a program where faculty members describe their interests and areas of expertise. Students attend these talks, meet potential advisors, and learn about the program's expectations.

qa_list.question: What happens during LTI Orientation Faculty Research Talks?
qa_list.answer: During these talks, faculty members present their interests and areas of expertise. Students attend to meet potential advisors and learn about the program's expectations.

qa_list.question: What is the role of Program Director in advisor selection process?
qa_list.answer: The Program Director approves student-advisor relationships, assigns an advisor if a student doesn't find one within the first month and oversees the advising process.

qa_list.question: What are the expectations for students attending LTI Orientation Faculty Research Talks?
qa_list.answer: Students are expected to attend these talks and treat them as seriously as a course, because they provide a good introduction to the broad range of research done at the LTI.

qa_list.question: Is there any registration or grading system for attending LTI Orientation Faculty Research Talks?
qa_list.answer: No, students do not have to register for the LTI Orientation Faculty Research Talks and they do not receive a grade.

qa_list.question: What is the purpose of the LTI Orientation Canvas course?
qa_list.answer: The LTI Orientation Canvas course is designed to increase incoming LTI graduate students' awareness and understanding of CMU's community standards and the resources that CMU offers its students.

qa_list.question: Who enrolls MIIS students into the LTI Orientation Canvas course?
qa_list.answer: The program administrator enrolls MIIS students into the LTI Orientation Canvas course in early August.

qa_list.question: What is expected from MIIS students regarding completing assignments for the LTI Orientation Canvas course?
qa_list.answer: All MIIS students are expected to complete all assignments by the end of their first semester in the program.

qa_list.question: Where can graduate students find the Summary of Graduate Student Appeal and Grievance Procedures?
qa_list.answer: Graduate students will find the Summary of Graduate Student Appeal and Grievance Procedures on the Graduate Education Resource webpage.

qa_list.question: What document summarizes MIIS Graduate Student Handbook?
qa_list.answer: The Summary of Graduate Student Appeal and Grievance Procedures in the MIIS Graduate Student Handbook summarizes MIIS Graduate Student Handbook.

qa_list.question: On which page can students find the summary of graduate student appeal and grievance procedures?
qa_list.answer: Students can find the Summary of Graduate Student Appeal and Grievance Procedures on Page 19 of the MIIS Graduate Student Handbook.

qa_list.question: What is the minimum QPA required for students to satisfy degree requirements?
Are pass/fail grades allowed in courses used to fulfill a degree requirement?
qa_list.answer: No, they are not permitted.

qa_list.question: Can graduate students elect the pass/fail option for additional undergraduate courses required to build up their core foundations of computer science?
qa_list.answer: No, they cannot do so.

qa_list.question: Are there any exceptions to the rule that prohibits pass/fail grades in degree-satisfying courses?
qa_list.answer: Yes, 11-696 (A) Capstone Planning Seminar and 11-935 (R) LTI Practicum are allowed as Pass/Fail.

qa_list.question: What is the page number in the MIIS Graduate Student Handbook where this rule about pass/fail grades can be found?
qa_list.answer: Page 20

qa_list.question: Can graduate students elect to take courses on a pass/fail basis for their degree requirements?
qa_list.answer: No, they cannot do so.

qa_list.question: What is the exception to this rule that allows certain courses to be taken as Pass/Fail grades?
qa_list.answer: 11-696 (A) Capstone Planning Seminar and 11-935 (R) LTI Practicum are allowed as Pass/Fail.

qa_list.question: What is the minimum QPA required for a student to satisfy degree requirements?
Are pass/fail grades permitted in courses used to fulfill degree requirements?
qa_list.answer: No, they are not allowed.

doc_text:
nting/.
2.1.3 Office Space for MS Students
To help create a sense of community, full time students in the LTI’s MIIS program have access to a shared office space.
2.1.4 Computers for MS Students
Students are expected to provide their own laptop computers that can be used to access university resources and complete course assignments. Laptops running Windows, MacOS, and Linux software are all acceptable.
Master’s students will be given a CS user id. A CS user id is required to use the LTI computer cluster, and other SCS services. The School of Computer Science has a Help Center located at
MIIS Graduate Student Handbook
Page 10


GHC 4201. They can be contacted at help@cs.cmu.edu, extension 8-4231 from a campus phone, or 412-268-4231 from an outside line.
MS students will be given access to the LTI’s computer cluster on an as-needed basis, to be used for course assignments, directed study projects, and/or the capstone project. The LTI cluster provides storage and computation for projects involving large datasets and/or lengthy computation.
3 CMU Degree Completion and Certification
3.1 Standard Degree Requirements & Degree Certification
Carnegie Mellon graduate students are expected to complete their degree requirements within the standard length of time for their program of study as outlined in the relevant Graduate Student Handbook. Standard program lengths for graduate students vary significantly ranging from two semesters for some full-time master’s programs to several or more years for doctoral programs. Upon completion of the graduate program degree requirements, the degree will be certified by the student’s academic program in the semester in which the student completes the requirements.
Early Completion Graduate students who consider the completion of all degree requirements in less than the standard length of time for their program of study may consult with their degree-granting program or department to determine if early degree certification is allowed and under what circumstances.
Extended or Longer-than-Standard Completion Longer-than-standard degree completion may occur due to academic interruptions in making progress toward the degree as defined by the academic program, interruptions of full-time study or progress towards the degree due to serious, documented medical issues, or other unusual or unforeseen circumstances.
Master’s students who require longer than the standard time to complete their degree requirements are expected to remain in close contact with their graduate program, and will be certified at the end of the semester in which they have completed their degree requirements. Students shall reference CMU Policy on Master’s Student Statute of Limitations: www.cmu.edu/policies/student-and-student-life/masters-students-statute-of limitations.html regarding guidelines and restrictions which place an upper limit on the maximum length of time allowable for master’s degree completion and certification.
MIIS Graduate Student Handbook
Page 11


3.2 Statute of Limitations
As outlined in the Master’s Students Statute of Limitations, https://www.cmu.edu/policies/student-and-student-life/masters-students-statute-of- limitations.html students will complete all requirements for the master’s degree within a maximum of seven years from original matriculation as a master’s student, or less if required by a more restrictive department, school or college policy. Once this time-to-degree limit has lapsed, the person may resume work towards a master’s degree only if newly admitted to a currently offered master’s degree program under criteria determined by that program.
Under extraordinary circumstances, such as leave of absence, military or public service, family or parental leave, or temporary disability, a school or college may, upon the relevant department's recommendation and with the written approval of the dean (or designate), defer the lapse for a period commensurate with the duration of that interruption. Students who are pursuing a master’s degree as part-time students for all semesters of their program, as approved by their program, may also appeal to their program or department for extension of the time to degree limit.
3.3 Additional Guidance for Students
Program of Study Students seeking guidance about their program of study and degree requirements should consult with their academic advisor and/or appropriate associate dean.
Financial Aid and Student Account Students are expected to make normal progress toward their degree in order to graduate within the standard timeframe for their program of study. Under U.S. Federal Title IV regulations, student eligibility for federal financial aid is contingent upon enrollment in and successful completion of courses that are counted as credit toward their current degree program. To receive the maximum amount of federal financial aid for which they may be eligible, students must enroll each semester in at least 36 units that count toward their current degree level. (See separate guidance regarding integrated degree completion.) Students should consult with their designated college liaison in The HUB regarding billing and financial aid, particularly for early completion, longer-than standard completion, or integrated undergraduate and master’s degree programs.
International Students Immigration status for students in F-1 and J-1 nonimmigrant status is tied to making normal progress toward completing degree requirements. Therefore, F-1 and J-1 students who are considering completing their degree requirements early, anticipating longer-than-standard completion, or moving from an undergraduate to a graduate student classification (integrated undergraduate-graduate study) should consult with their designated advisor in the Office of International Education (OIE) to ensure compliance with immigration regulations.
MIIS Graduate Student Handbook
Page 12


4 MIIS Degree Requirements and Related Policies/Protocols
4.1 Program Options
The MIIS degree is offered in two options:
Option 1. Standard MIIS degree (MIIS-16) - A 16-month track that is completed in three academic semesters (fall, spring, fall) and a summer internship.
Option 2. MIIS: Advanced Study degree (MIIS-21) - A 21-month track that is completed in four academic semesters (fall, spring, fall, spring) and a summer internship.
MIIS: Advanced Study track offers in depth degree in one of the following areas of concentration:
Human Language for Language Technologies • Language Technology Application • Machine Learning for Language Technologies
Part-time options are available in some cases.
4.2 Required Units for Degree Attainment
To complete the Master of Science in Intelligent Information Systems, a student must satisfy three types of requirements. Curricular requirements ensure that MIIS students receive instruction in core intelligent information systems technologies while also allowing an opportunity to specialize in areas of personal interest. Practice requirements are opportunities to apply and hone new skills while building state-of-the-art systems. Grade requirements ensure that students have demonstrated a certain level of skill while completing degree requirements. All three types of requirements are described below.
MIIS-16 students must take at least 84 units (typically 7 12-unit courses) of qualifying and elective courses that satisfy human language, machine learning, and language technology applications breadth requirements and 66 practice units for a total of 150 units to attain the Standard MIIS degree.
MIIS-21 students must take at least 108 units (typically 9 12-unit courses) of qualifying and elective courses and 66 practice units to satisfy their degree requirements, making it a total of 174 units to attain the MIIS: Advanced Study degree.
4.3 Core Requirements
MIIS Graduate Student Handbook
Page 13


A MIIS student must complete the following curricular requirements:
1. Qualifying courses:
MIIS-16 students must pass 72 units (typically 6 12-unit courses) and MIIS-21 students must complete 96 units (typically 8 12-unit courses) in qualifying master’s courses.
A qualifying master’s course is defined as:
a. Any graduate course (600-level or higher) offered by the Language Technologies
Institute; and
b. Any graduate course (600-level or higher) from the list of approved qualifying
courses (Section 3.2.4).
2. Free elective: Students must pass 12 units (typically 1 course) in elective master’s course(s). A free elective is defined as:
a. A graduate course (600-level or higher) with content relevant to the MIIS
program objectives offered by the School of Computer Science; and
b. A course approved by the student's advisor and the degree Program Director. c. A student may not use the same course to satisfy both a qualifying course
requirement and an elective course requirement.
3. Breadth requirements: Students must demonstrate breadth by passing one course in each of the following areas. In addition, MIIS-21 students must take two more LTI courses (24 units total) in one of the following areas of concentration:
Human language; • Machine learning; and • Language technology applications.
The department maintains and publishes a list of courses that satisfy each of these requirements (Sections 3.2.5 – 3.2.7). Some courses used to satisfy a breadth requirement can also satisfy qualifying course requirements. A student should get approval from the director for the breadth courses, if not listed below.
4.4 Approved Qualifying Courses
Any graduate course (600-level or higher) offered by the Language Technologies Institute is a qualifying course.
Any two graduate courses (600-level or higher) offered by departments within the SCS relevant to the MIIS degree other than LTI (Machine Learning or Computer Science departments, etc.) may be counted as approved qualifying courses.
MIIS Graduate Student Handbook
Page 14


Any course from the following list is an approved qualifying course.
02-712, Computational Methods for Biological Modeling and Simulation • 05-631, Software Structures for User interfaces • 05-813, Human Factors • • • • 10-708, Probabilistic Graphical Models 16-720, Computer Vision 17-631 Information Security, Privacy & Policy 17-781, Mobile and IoT Computing Services
4.4.1 Breadth Courses: Human Language
• • • • • •
11-611, Natural Language Processing 11-624, Human Language for Artificial Intelligence 11-711, Advanced NLP 11-722, Grammar Formalisms 11-724, Human Language for Artificial Intelligence 11-727, Computational Semantics for NLP 11-737, Multilingual NLP
4.4.2 Breadth Courses: Language Technology Applications
• • • • • • •
11-642, Search Engines 11-688, Concepts in Digital Multimedia and Cyber Forensics 11-692, Speech Processing 11-697. Introduction to Question Answering 11-751, Speech Recognition and Understanding 11-767, On-Service Machine Learning 11-797, Question Answering 11-830, Computational Ethics For NLP
4.4.3 Breadth Courses: Machine Learning
• • • • • •
11-641, Machine Learning for Text and Graph-Based Mining 11-661, Language and Statistics 11-663, Applied Machine Learning 11-747, Neural Networks for NLP 11-755, Machine Learning for Signal Processing 11-761, Language and Statistics 11-777, Multimodal Machine Learning
MIIS Graduate Student Handbook
Page 15


• • • • • • •
11-785, Introduction to Deep Learning 10-601, Introduction to Machine Learning (Master’s) 10-605, Machine Learning with Large Datasets 10-701, Introduction to Machine Learning (PhD) 10-707, Advanced Deep Learning 10-708, Probabilistic Graphical Models 10-714, Deep Learning Systems 10-715, Advanced Introduction to Machine Learning
4.5 Practice Requirements
A student must complete at least 66 practice-oriented course units and satisfy the following practice-oriented requirements for both MIIS-16 and MIIS-21 programs.
1. Directed study requirement: Students must pass 24 units (typically 12 units x 2 semesters) in directed study under the supervision of their advisor. Directed study is a structured, task-oriented form of independent study that provides deep, hands-on experience in a particular technology area and an opportunity to work closely with a member of the faculty.
2. Internship requirement: Students must complete a one-semester (typically summer) internship at an organization (typically a company or government agency) approved by the MIIS Program Director. Internships are an opportunity to apply new skills in a professional setting and to learn about software development in a ‘real world’ organization. Students with prior professional experience may petition the MIIS Program Director to waive this requirement. MIIS students that do an internship during the summer semester are required to present their internship at a poster session at the beginning of the following Fall semester. The poster and the student’s participation in the poster session are part of the internship requirement. Participation is required unless waived in writing by the MIIS Program Director.
3. Capstone requirements: Students must complete a capstone project (36 units) and a capstone planning seminar (6 units). The capstone requirement gives students experience with collaborative, team-oriented software development; significant hands- on experience with the techniques studied in the classroom; and an opportunity to work on a large software application. a. The capstone project (36 units) is a large, group-oriented demonstration of student skill in one or more areas covered by the degree. Typically, the result of the capstone project is a major software application. The capstone project is supervised by a member of the faculty who meets with students on a weekly basis to monitor progress and provide guidance.
MIIS Graduate Student Handbook
Page 16


b. The capstone planning seminar (6 units) organizes students into groups; defines capstone project goals, requirements, success metrics, and deliverables; and identifies and acquires data, software, and other resources required for successful completion of the project. The planning seminar must be completed in the semester prior to taking the capstone project.
4.6 Registration Process/Procedures
Students are responsible for registering for their courses. Use the Stellic Degree Audit Application to monitor your progress and plan your degree. Students can search for relevant courses in a number of ways and share your plan with your advisor directly through the application.
Navigate to the SIO Academic Info tab and select Enrollment Status and the upcoming
semester to confirm the following:
Enrollment Status is 'Eligible to Enroll' (if not, email thehub@andrew.cmu.edu) • Maximum units for which you can plan to register for (overloads are reviewed and permitted only after registration week)
Class Level, College and Department are correct (if incorrect, please contact your home
academic department)
The registration process can be completed within SIO (Student Information Online) by following 4 easy steps: https://www.cmu.edu/hub/registrar/docs/4-easy-steps.pdf
If students have any questions about course selection, students may reach out to MIIS program director, Teruko Mitamura.
4.7 Drop/Add/Withdraw Procedures
Students taking undergraduate and master’s level courses must follow the procedures and deadlines for adding, dropping, or withdrawing from courses as identified on the academic calendar. Information can be found at https://www.cmu.edu/hub/registrar/course- changes/index.html. Please note that there is a separate calendar for doctoral courses that does not apply to Masters’ students.
4.8 Transfer Courses and Pittsburgh Council on Higher Education (PCHE)
MIIS Graduate Student Handbook
Page 17


Carnegie Mellon University offers students the opportunity to take courses for credit through a cross-registration program (see Pittsburgh Council on Higher Education (PCHE) and Cross- registration below) and through the receipt of transfer credit from other accredited institutions. The Carnegie Mellon University transcript will include information on such courses as follows: Carnegie Mellon courses and courses taken through the university's cross- registration program will have grades recorded on the transcript and be factored into the QPA. All other courses will be recorded on this transcript indicating where the course was taken, but without grades. Such courses will not be considered for academic actions, honors or QPA calculations.
https://www.cmu.edu/policies/student-and-student-life/transfer-credit-evaluation-and- assignment.html
NOTE: Suspended students may take courses elsewhere; however, they may receive transfer credit only if their college’s and department's policies allow this.
4.9 Internships
If the experience will have units attached to it, the program should have deliverables from the student commensurate with the number of units they are taking. This can be in the form of interim and final reports on the experience, presentations in the following semester regarding the experience, assessments of their experience as it relates to their course of study, etc. Students are responsible for identifying and applying for internships on their own. The LTI and the university provide several types of support for students seeking internships.
An annual poster session helps spread information from MIIS students that recently completed internships to MIIS students that will soon seek internships; other LTI professional master’s programs have similar internship-oriented poster sessions that MIIS students may attend. The university offers resume-writing and interviewing workshops to help prepare students and fall and spring employment fairs to help students connect with companies. The university’s Career & Professional Development Center https://www.cmu.edu/career/ provides other services as well.
If a student cannot find an internship, the MIIS program will arrange an on-campus internship with a university-based project. This internship may be unpaid.
International students are required to consult with Office of International Education for eligibility before seeking an internship/co-op or signing an offer contract (required addition to ensure the university is in compliance with immigration laws for F & J status students).
4.10 Advising
MIIS Graduate Student Handbook
Page 18


Each student has a faculty advisor charged with guiding the education and monitoring the progress of the student through the program. The advisor also supervises the student's directed study projects. This personal student-advisor relationship ensures that every student receives the necessary faculty mentoring. The advisor also provides the student with career advice.
How and when the advisor is selected: Advisors are selected during the first month of the program. Students are expected to attend the LTI Orientation Faculty Research Talks in which faculty describe their interests and areas of expertise, and to be proactive about meeting individually with potential advisors. Typically, if a student and faculty member agree to enter an advising relationship, it is approved by the Program Director. If a student has not found an advisor after one month in the program, the Program Director will assign an advisor to the student.
How to change advisors: The initial advisor selection should be made carefully. However, it is possible to change advisors. To do so, the student should find another faculty member willing to serve as an advisor, and then make a request to the Program Director to switch advisors. The LTI follows the long-standing SCS policy that both the new and old advisors need to agree to the change; typically, this is not a problem, assuming the new advisor has agreed in advance, as described here. It is to the student's advantage to avoid switching advisors, especially late in their graduate studies, because forging a strong student-advisor relationship takes time.
4.11 LTI Orientation
Prior to the beginning of each Fall semester the LTI provides lectures and faculty research talks to help students learn about the work done by CMU faculty and to provide an opportunity for advisors to recruit new students. Students are expected to attend them and to treat them as seriously as a course, because they provide a good introduction to the broad range of research done at the LTI. Students do not have to register for the LTI Orientation Faculty Research Talks, nor do they receive a grade, however the department is serious about its expectation that new students will attend these talks.
The LTI Orientation Canvas course is a mandatory course designed to increase incoming LTI graduate students' awareness and understanding of CMU's community standards and the resources that CMU offers the students. The course includes several administrative tasks, training, and educational sessions. The students will be enrolled into the course by the program administrator in early August. All MIIS students are expected to complete all assignments by the end of their first semester in the program. Each assignment has its own due date.
4.12 Summary of Graduate Student Appeal and Grievance Procedures
Graduate students will find the Summary of Graduate Student Appeal and Grievance Procedures on the Graduate Education Resource webpage. This document summarizes
MIIS Graduate Student Handbook
Page 19


processes available to graduate students who seek review of academic and non-academic issues. Generally, graduate students are expected to seek informal resolution of all concerns within the applicable department, unit, or program before invoking formal processes. When an informal resolution cannot be reached, however, a graduate student who seeks further review of the matter is to follow the formal procedures outlined here. These appeal and grievance procedures shall apply to students in all graduate programs of the University. Students should refer to the department specific information in this handbook for department and college information about the administration and academic policies of the program.
Summary of Graduate Student Appeal and Grievance Procedures - Office of Graduate and Postdoctoral Affairs - Carnegie Mellon University (cmu.edu)
4.13 Intellectual Property Policy
The MIIS degree program adheres to Carnegie Mellon University policy on intellectual property: http://www.cmu.edu/policies/documents/IntellProp.html
5 Grading and Evaluation
5.1 Grading Scale/System
Students must demonstrate their mastery of material taught in courses and their success in applying their skills in directed study and capstone projects by satisfying the following grade requirements:
1. Minimum grade: A student must obtain a B- or better grade in all courses, which count towards core requirements. If a student receives a C or better, that course may count as an elective towards the degree requirements.
2. Minimum QPA: A student must maintain an average QPA of at least 3.0 in courses and projects used to satisfy degree requirements.
3. Pass/fail: Pass/fail grades are not permitted for courses and projects used to satisfy a degree requirement. Graduate students who are required to take additional undergraduate courses to build up the core foundations of computer science may not elect the pass/fail option for these courses.
5.2 Pass/Fail Grades
Pass/fail grades are not permitted for courses used to satisfy a degree requirement, except for the 11-696 (A) Capstone Planning Seminar and 11-935 (R) LTI Practicum that are a Pass/Fail.
MIIS Graduate Student Handbook
Page 20


Graduate students who are required to take additional undergraduate courses to build up the core foundations of computer science may not elect the pass/fail option for these courses.
5.3 Independent Study
An independent study can be counted as an Elective course, but it cannot be counted as a Qualifying course.
5.4 University Policy on Grades
This policy offers details concerning university grading principles for students taking courses and covers the specifics of assigning and changing grades, grading options, drop/withdrawals, and course repeats. It also defines the undergraduate and graduate grading standards.
https://www.cmu.edu/policies/student-and-student-life/grading.html
5.5 Process for Appealing Final Grades
Final grades will be changed only in exceptional circumstances and only with the approval of the instructor and the department, unit or program. Grading is a matter of sound discretion of the instructor and final grades are rarely changed without the consent of the instructor who assigned the grade. The following circumstances are the unusual exceptions that may warrant a grade appeal: (a) the final grade assigned for a course is based on manifest error (e.g., a clear error such as arithmetic error in computing a grade or failure to grade one of the answers on an exam), or (b) the faculty or staff member who assigned the grade did so in violation of a university policy.
Summary of Graduate Student Appeal and Grievance Procedures - Office of Graduate and Postdoctoral Affairs - Carnegie Mellon University (cmu.edu)
5.6 Policy on Grades for Transfer Courses
Carnegie Mellon University offers students the opportunity to take courses for credit through a cross-registration program (see Pittsburgh Council on Higher Education (PCHE) and Cross- registration below) and through the receipt of transfer credit from other accredited institutions. The Carnegie Mellon Unive
